body.p:
Yours from Baltimore I duly
received but have been unable to acknowledge it till
now. You are more fortunate than I in being able to
run about and get a little recreation. I had fully determined
to take a short time about the country but L'homme proposes
et Dieu disposes. I put it off till this week when a
child of Mr Moss dies of cholera and I am fixed, a veritable
Hebrew. In respect to “the mystery in connection with a
lady in Montreal” I have to remark (the ladies of course
claiming first attention from we modern Rabbanim)since
S Selig newman says in a sermon preached at the London
Jewish free school, “the key ? used formerly to be Hebrew
but now, complains newman, perhaps from actual
experience poor fellow, “it is Hebrew”, the Lecture
meant no doubt pathetically to say we had been Hebrew
enough, and so allowed the ladies to turn & ? at us
in the Hebrew form.) but to ? from this long
parenthesis to the “mystery” Did I mention my lady?
Certainly not and yet you seem very anxious to assure
me that “nothing has ever passed between us”? who
are us? You are one, and who is the second—Oh
you guilty man! You can't keep a secret too, I find.
It is certainly very kind of you to hope the lady wont
refuse a good match, even myself, in your account after I already

wrote you that I would not stand in your way (?
of me.) But seriously, my respected friend, I do not presume
to suggest myself less to dictate to you who shall be your partner if what
you tell me will be the downward course of your life,
nor when you shall take her. You are better competent
to decide these yourself, I hope that the little M?
at banter in which I have indulged may have been
not agreable to you In dismissing (for the present!)
this soft subject let me say in justice to the young
ladies to whom we have alluded that we might
both “go farther and fail worse” As for me, my dear
friend, if you find yourself “not in a situation to
marry”, I also find myself in such a situation. You
only hold your situation for a year longer, I have
mine for three only, from present date, Besides “I
am not young” and am too busily employed for
self and others to think of marriage for a few years
and Hebrew When I have done a little more (if I may
be presumptuous enough to say I have done anything) for
the cause I shall then be entitled to spend a few
hours in the pleasures of domesticity as
a reward for my work. You are now fully entitled
to such a partial rest, and nothing would afford
me greater pleasure than to receive a call from you
to introduce you (Hebrew into the happy ?
At the same time I confess that it would be a little
gratifying to me if I were in a position to ask the same of you.

It was with regret and surprise that I recd your account
of the manner in which you as yet find yourself remunerated
for your writings, thus, mon ami, le temps viendra.

It would give me much pleasure to make the
acquaintance of Mrs as also of Mr Cohen of Baltimore,
persons of whom fame speaks so favorably here, I gave
Mrs Cohens message to Mrs ? Solomons, Mrs S desires
me to ask you when you are going to New Orleans
Mr Touro of that place is related to them, and you
know how it is when we have rich relations, we like
to know something of their whereabouts. She would
also like to know where Mr Touro is living in New Orleans
I gave your message to Mr Jacob Joseph, but as his
brother Pepe and sister Esther are in your city you
can make your own explanations to the Hebrew

The Occident for September has not arrived yet
so cannot say anything on matters literary, The
articles on the Jews of Persia I shall not be able to
commense untill after Hebrew. It is seldom or never
that I stipulate for special time for the Oc my articles
but in the case of sermons I do, I have published
scarcely other than occasional sermons which
loose their interest and effect when the cause or
event they speak upon is part. Thus my
Sermon on the cholera would have been much more
seasonable reading for your readers while the
epidemic prevailed, and might have been to me
more effect, so a sermon I sent you for

Hebrew was published a “day after the fair” In future I must
trouble you to let me know when I send a sermon whether
it can be published at the time required as I would then
prefer its not being published at all if not at the
specified time.

You have been made aware long before this of the
visit of Dr Raphael and Dr Isaacs to the United States.
The latter ? avowedly to seek for a situation in America
the former to make a little fortune by lecturing
and as the chronicle tells us will no doubt be
permanently engaged in the United States. I hope
both these gentlemen for their sakes will not find
themselves mistaken. I am not sanguine enough
of you Yankee Israelites to believe that Dr Raphael
will find a better situation than the one he filled
at Birmingham & which yielded him £500 sterling
It would be uncharitable to believe all that is said
of Mr D Isaacs, but he was spoke of both in
London and elsewhere as possessing a temper not at all
likely to ? success. Let me hear what you
think of the contemplated visits. I have now written
your ? fully and must therefore close. Wishing
you many happy returns of the coming Hebrew
and praying that the coming year may be to
you Hebrew
